title: Driving in Spain: License, Rules & Buying a Car
excerpt: Complete guide to driving in Spain for expats: using foreign licenses, exchanging your license at DGT, buying cars (costs €4,000-€50,000+), ITV (MOT), insurance, and Spanish traffic rules.
author: New Build Homes Costa Blanca

content.quickAnswer: EU driving licenses are valid in Spain for 2 years; non-EU licenses for 6 months. You can exchange your license at DGT (Dirección General de Tráfico). Buying a car costs €4,000–€50,000+ (new and used options available). Insurance is mandatory (terceros liability minimum €600–€1,000/year). Spanish traffic rules include 50 km/h in towns, 100 km/h on normal roads, 120 km/h on motorways.
content.intro: For expats relocating to the Costa Blanca, owning a car is often essential for commuting, exploring the region, and enjoying the Mediterranean lifestyle. However, driving in Spain involves navigating different rules, licensing requirements, insurance obligations, and car purchase processes compared to your home country. This guide provides practical information on driving licenses, buying a car (whether new or used), vehicle registration and inspection (ITV), insurance, traffic rules, common fines, and safety considerations for foreign drivers on the Costa Blanca.

sections.title: Driving Licenses: Foreign Licenses and License Exchange

subsections.heading: Using Your Foreign Driving License in Spain
subsections.content: When you first arrive in Spain, you can drive on your valid foreign driving license without immediate legal obligation to exchange it. However, the duration you can drive on a foreign license depends on your citizenship: (1) EU/EEA citizens: Your license is valid for driving in Spain for 2 years from when you establish residency in Spain. (2) Non-EU citizens: Your license is valid for 6 months from arrival in Spain. (3) International Driving Permits (IDPs): Citizens of countries not signatory to the Vienna Convention on Road Signs and Signals (e.g., Australia, some Asian countries) should obtain an IDP from their home country authorities before arriving. An IDP is a translation of your license and must be accompanied by your original license to be valid in Spain. Most EU licenses (UK, France, Germany, Scandinavia, etc.) are recognized in Spain. Your license must be in good condition and not expired; Spain does not accept expired licenses regardless of citizenship. If your license is in your home-country language (e.g., English), you should carry it along with an official translation into Spanish or carry an IDP, though in practice Spanish police are usually accommodating with EU license holders and do not strictly require translations.

subsections.heading: Exchanging Your License at the DGT (Dirección General de Tráfico)
subsections.content: At some point during your residency in Spain (ideally within the first 2 years for EU citizens, within 6 months for non-EU citizens), you should exchange your foreign license for a Spanish driving license (permiso de conducción). This is not legally mandatory if you have a valid foreign EU license (you can drive indefinitely in Spain on a valid EU license), but exchanging to a Spanish license is recommended for convenience and proof of Spanish residency. To exchange your license: (1) Visit the DGT (Dirección General de Tráfico) office in your province. On the Costa Blanca, major DGT offices are in Alicante, Torrevieja, Benidorm, and Javea. (2) Complete an application form (Modelo TT.2), available at the DGT or online. (3) Provide: your foreign license (original), passport (original), two passport-size photographs, proof of Spanish residency (empadronamiento—municipal registration, or a utility bill), and a Spanish tax ID number (NIE for foreigners). (4) Pay a processing fee (approximately €25–€35). (5) Take a medical certificate if required (most exchanges for standard categories do not require medical exams unless you have certain health conditions or the original license is very old). The DGT will issue a temporary license on the spot and mail the permanent license within 2–4 weeks. During this period, you can drive using your original foreign license plus the temporary receipt. The entire process takes 30 minutes to 1 hour.

subsections.heading: License Categories and Restrictions
subsections.content: Spanish driving license categories are similar to EU standards: (1) AM (mopeds up to 50cc): From age 16. (2) A1 (motorcycles up to 125cc): From age 16. (3) A (motorcycles any size): From age 24 (or 20 with 2-year experience on A1). (4) B (cars up to 3,500 kg): From age 18. Most expats hold a Category B license. (5) C (lorries up to 7,500 kg): From age 18 (for hire), age 21 (professional). (6) D (buses): From age 24. Your foreign license's categories typically transfer directly to the Spanish license without additional testing. However, if your foreign license has restrictions (e.g., 'automatic transmission only'), these carry over to your Spanish license. Category B allows driving cars and light vans and pulling trailers up to a certain weight.

subsections.heading: Driving License Validity and Renewal
subsections.content: Spanish driving licenses expire (unlike some countries with no expiration): (1) Ages 18–45: Valid for 10 years. (2) Ages 45–70: Valid for 5 years. (3) Ages 70+: Valid for 3 years (with more frequent medical examinations required). Renewal requires visiting the DGT with your expiring license, passport, medical certificate (for ages 70+), and payment of a renewal fee (approximately €20–€30). It is advisable to renew your license before it expires; driving on an expired license is illegal and incurs fines. If your Spanish license is approaching expiration, the DGT typically sends renewal information, though you should proactively check the expiration date and schedule renewal in advance.

sections.title: Buying a Car in Spain: New and Used Options

subsections.heading: Overview: Cost Range and Market
subsections.content: Cars in Spain are available across a wide price range: (1) Used economy cars (5–15 years old): €4,000–€8,000. Examples: Fiat Panda, Renault Clio, Volkswagen Polo. (2) Used mid-range cars (3–10 years old): €8,000–€20,000. Examples: Peugeot 308, Seat Ibiza, Ford Focus. (3) New economy cars: €12,000–€20,000. (4) New mid-range cars: €20,000–€35,000. (5) Luxury/premium cars: €35,000–€100,000+. Car prices in Spain are generally comparable to other European countries, though some models are more expensive in Spain due to import taxes and local pricing. On the Costa Blanca, both new and used car markets are active. Dealerships (concesionarios) are common, particularly for franchised dealers (Renault, Seat, Peugeot, Ford, etc.), and private sales are also prevalent. Second-hand car markets are robust, with numerous classified websites (milanuncios.com, motos.net, Coches.net) listing private and dealer vehicles.

subsections.heading: Buying a New Car
subsections.content: Purchasing a new car from a dealership in Spain is straightforward: (1) Choose your vehicle and negotiate price (dealer discounts of 5–15% below sticker price are common). (2) Agree on specifications (color, options, delivery timeline). (3) Sign a sales contract (contrato de compra-venta) specifying vehicle details, price, delivery date, and payment terms. (4) Typically, a deposit (10–20% of price) is paid upon signing; the balance is paid upon delivery. (5) Arrange financing if needed (see financing section below). (6) The dealer arranges vehicle registration and provides the documentation (title, registration certificate) upon delivery. (7) The dealer registers the car in your name at the municipality's traffic office (jefatura provincial de tráfico) and provides registration plates. Registration and documentation typically take 2–4 weeks after payment. A new car includes warranty (typically 3 years or 100,000 km), roadside assistance (often included), and insurance (initially included in some cases). VAT (IVA, 21% in Spain) is included in the sticker price; you cannot claim VAT back unless you are a VAT-registered business. Purchase price for a new economy car (€15,000) includes approximately €3,150 VAT.

subsections.heading: Buying a Used Car
subsections.content: Buying a used car is common and economical, particularly for those on a budget: (1) From a private seller: Use classified sites (milanuncios.com, coches.net) or local advertisements. Inspect the car thoroughly, request service history and maintenance records, and test-drive extensively. (2) Verify ownership: Ask the seller for the registration document (título) and ensure they are the registered owner. (3) Check vehicle condition: Have a trusted mechanic inspect the car (inspection costs €80–€150). (4) Negotiate price: Used car prices are negotiable; expect 5–10% discount from asking price. (5) Sign a sales contract: Even private sales should be documented in writing (modelo 030 form, available online). (6) Register the car: Transfer ownership at the municipal traffic office (jefatura provincial de tráfico) by presenting the old registration, new owner information, sales contract, and proof of ITV (see below). Registration transfer costs approximately €100–€200 and takes 1–2 weeks. (7) From a dealer: Dealer purchases offer more protection (warranty, checked condition), but prices are higher. Dealers typically offer 12-month warranties on used cars and handle registration. Used car purchases do not incur VAT on the resale; however, if you buy from a dealer, there may be transfer taxes (variación de titularidad) of approximately 4–8% depending on the municipality.

subsections.heading: Financing and Insurance During Purchase
subsections.content: (1) Financing: Spanish banks and dealerships offer car loans (préstamos para vehículos) at interest rates of 3–7% depending on credit history and loan term. Foreigners with Spanish NIE and established residence can typically obtain car loans; you may need to provide proof of income and establish a Spanish bank account. (2) Down payment: Most loans require a 10–20% down payment. (3) Loan term: Typically 3–7 years; longer terms mean lower monthly payments but higher total interest. (4) Pre-purchase insurance: Some sellers require proof of insurance before you take possession of the car. You can arrange temporary insurance online (1–3 days) while permanent insurance is being finalized. (5) Tax implications: Car purchases are not subject to transfer tax (unlike property), but registration includes administrative fees (approximately €100–€200). See the insurance section below for insurance options.

subsections.heading: Vehicle Registration (Matrícula) and Documentation
subsections.content: When you purchase a car, it must be registered in your name at the municipal traffic office (jefatura provincial de tráfico). Spanish vehicle registration includes: (1) Title document (certificado de registro de propiedad): Proof of ownership, issued by the traffic office. (2) Registration certificate (permiso de circulación): Document certifying the car is roadworthy and registered. (3) Technical inspection certificate (inspección técnica de vehículos, or ITV): Required for cars over 4 years old (see below). (4) Registration plates (matrícula): Spanish plates consist of four digits followed by three letters (e.g., 1234 ABC). Plates are assigned by the traffic office and are unique to the vehicle. When you register a car, the traffic office issues plates, which must be installed before the car is driven on public roads. Registration is processed at the provincial traffic office; on the Costa Blanca, offices are in Alicante (provincial capital), Torrevieja, Benidorm, and other major municipalities. Registration typically takes 1–2 weeks after documents are submitted.

subsections.heading: ITV (Inspección Técnica de Vehículos) - Spain's MOT Equivalent
subsections.content: The ITV is Spain's mandatory vehicle safety and emissions inspection, equivalent to the UK MOT. (1) When required: Cars must have ITV inspection if they are more than 4 years old. (2) Frequency: Every 2 years for cars 4–40 years old; annually for cars over 40 years old. (3) What is checked: Structural integrity, brakes, lights, steering, suspension, emissions, windscreen, wipers, seatbelts, registration plates, safety equipment (warning triangles, reflective jackets). (4) Cost: Approximately €60–€120 per inspection depending on the testing center (taller de ITV). (5) Pass/fail: If you pass, you receive a certificate valid for 2 years. If you fail, you have 2 months to fix the issues and retest (second test is discounted, approximately €30–€50). (6) Booking: You can book ITV appointments online (e.g., through regional ITV center websites) or in person. Appointment times are available within 1–2 weeks typically. (7) Necessity before purchase: When buying a used car, ensure it has valid ITV; if ITV is expired, you cannot legally drive the car until inspection is completed. As a buyer, request ITV certificate from the seller; if it is expired, budget €60–€120 for inspection as part of your purchase cost.

subsections.heading: Registration Transfer for Foreigners
subsections.content: As a foreign national purchasing a car in Spain, registration requires: (1) Your Spanish NIE (foreigner identification number), obtained through your local police station or national immigration office. (2) Proof of Spanish residency: Empadronamiento (municipal registration) or a utility bill. (3) Completed registration forms (modelo 030 for new registrations, modelo 031 for transfers). (4) Passport. (5) Original documents: Sales contract, previous registration certificate (if used car), and ITV certificate. The registration office processes your application and issues the registration certificate and plates within 1–2 weeks. Cars are registered in your personal name; you cannot register a car in your spouse's name unless they also have a Spanish NIE. Some expats register cars in the name of a Spanish business entity; consult a Spanish accountant or lawyer if this is relevant to your situation (e.g., if purchasing a car for a rental business).

subsections.heading: Insurance Mandate and Types
subsections.content: Car insurance is legally mandatory in Spain. All drivers must have at least liability insurance (Responsabilidad Civil) covering damage to third parties (other vehicles, property, persons). Two main insurance types are offered: (1) Terceros (Liability-only): Basic mandatory insurance covering damage you cause to third parties. Does not cover damage to your own vehicle, theft, vandalism, or accidents where you are at fault. Annual cost: €600–€1,000 for a standard car in most of Spain. (2) Todo Riesgo (Comprehensive): Covers liability to third parties plus damage to your vehicle (accidents, theft, vandalism, weather, natural disasters). Includes additional benefits like roadside assistance, rental car while yours is being repaired, and legal assistance. Annual cost: €1,000–€3,000+ depending on car value, driver age/experience, and deductible (franchise). Comprehensive insurance is recommended for new or financed cars; most lenders require it as a loan condition. For older, low-value cars, liability-only may be economical.

subsections.heading: Insurance Premiums and Factors
subsections.content: Your insurance premium depends on: (1) Type of car: Newer, safer cars (with electronic stability control, airbags, etc.) have lower premiums. Sports cars and expensive vehicles cost more to insure. (2) Car value: Higher-value cars cost more to insure (for comprehensive coverage). (3) Driver age and experience: Young drivers (under 25) and new drivers (0–3 years experience) pay significantly higher premiums (50–100% more). Drivers over 75 pay higher premiums. (4) Driving record: Clean driving records (no accidents, no fines) result in lower premiums. Each accident increases your premium (up to 50% increase); at-fault accidents increase premiums more than non-fault. (5) Annual mileage: Higher mileage increases premiums (more exposure to risk). (6) Deductible (franchise): Higher deductibles (€300–€1,000) lower premiums but mean you pay more if you have an accident. (7) Claims history: Insurance companies penalize drivers with previous claims. (8) Location: Rural vs. urban areas have different risk profiles; coastal areas like the Costa Blanca may have slightly different rates than inland regions. Example premium: A 40-year-old driver with a clean record insuring a 5-year-old economy car (€12,000 value) with liability-only in the Costa Blanca region would expect to pay €700–€900/year. Comprehensive for the same car/driver would be €1,200–€1,600/year.

subsections.heading: Obtaining Insurance
subsections.content: Insurance is available through: (1) Traditional insurers: AXA, Allianz, Mapfre, Seguros Bilbao (direct offices and online). (2) Online-only insurers: Rastreator.es, Seguros.es (comparison sites and direct brokers). (3) Dealerships: When purchasing from a dealer, they often arrange insurance. (4) Brokers: Insurance brokers (corredores de seguros) can provide quotes from multiple companies. (5) Online comparison: Use comparison sites (rastreator.es, CompareTheMarket.es) to compare quotes across insurers. The process: Provide your information (car details, driver age/experience, driving history, desired coverage), receive quotes, select a policy, pay (usually monthly installments or annual payment), and receive documentation. Most policies include roadside assistance (grúa), legal assistance (asesoramiento legal), and sometimes rental car while yours is repaired. Policies are typically annual; renewal happens automatically unless you cancel. You can switch insurers annually if you find better rates elsewhere. Cancellation requires written notice (usually 30 days before expiration); some brokers will handle this for you.

subsections.heading: Mandatory Insurance Documentation
subsections.content: Carry your insurance documents (póliza de seguro) in the car at all times. Spanish law requires you to produce insurance proof when requested by police. Increasingly, insurers provide digital proof (app-based or email), which is acceptable. Additionally, all cars must carry: (1) Reflective safety vests (at least one per passenger, increasingly required), (2) Warning triangles (at least two), (3) Headlight bulbs/spares (not mandatory but recommended), (4) Breathalyzer kit (not mandatory but carrying one reduces fines if stopped). These items cost €30–€50 total and are available at service stations and car parts stores.

subsections.heading: Speed Limits
subsections.content: (1) Towns and cities (zona urbana): 50 km/h (31 mph). This applies to all roads with street lights or in built-up areas. (2) Outside towns, normal roads: 90 km/h (56 mph). (3) Dual carriageways (autopistas de dos carriles): 100 km/h (62 mph). (4) Motorways (autopistas de acceso limitado): 120 km/h (75 mph). Excess speed fines: (1) Exceeding the limit by 1–20 km/h: €100–€300 fine. (2) Exceeding by 21–40 km/h: €300–€600 fine, possible license suspension. (3) Exceeding by 41+ km/h: €600–€1,000 fine, 4–6 month license suspension. Speed cameras (radares) are common on the Costa Blanca, especially on motorways and major roads. Fixed cameras and mobile radar units enforce limits.

subsections.heading: Roundabouts and Right-of-Way Rules
subsections.content: Spanish roundabouts (rotondas) require: (1) Yield to traffic already in the roundabout (vehicles on your right have priority if entering together). (2) Use right turn signal (derecha) when exiting. (3) Stay in the right lane if taking the first exit. (4) Cross to the left lane for later exits. (5) Do not undertake (pass on the right/inside of vehicles in the roundabout). Most Spanish roundabouts are well-marked; follow signs and lane markings carefully. At intersections without roundabouts, priority is given to the right (prioritario a la derecha) unless signs indicate otherwise—this means traffic coming from your right has priority. Stop signs (señal de stop, octagonal red sign) require a complete stop; yield signs (señal de ceda el paso, triangular sign) require yielding. Pedestrian crossings (pasos de cebra, zebra stripes) must be respected; you must stop and allow pedestrians to cross. Running a red light is dangerous and results in a €200 fine.

subsections.heading: Seatbelts and Child Restraints
subsections.content: Seatbelts are legally mandatory for all occupants (driver and all passengers). Failure to wear a seatbelt results in a €200 fine. Child restraints (asientos de seguridad) are mandatory based on age and height: (1) Ages 0–15 months or under 76 cm: Rear-facing infant car seats. (2) Ages 15 months–4 years or 76–105 cm: Forward-facing child seats. (3) Ages 4–12 years or 105–150 cm: Booster seats or high-back boosters. (4) Over 150 cm or age 12+: Standard seatbelts. Violation results in €200 fines and potential child welfare involvement. Car seats are available for purchase or rent at most major retailers (€50–€300 depending on type).

subsections.heading: Alcohol and Drug Driving
subsections.content: Spain has strict drunk and drug driving laws: (1) Blood alcohol limit: 0.5 mg/dL for general drivers, 0.3 mg/dL for new drivers (less than 2 years) and professional drivers. (2) Breath alcohol limit: 0.25 mg/L for general drivers, 0.15 mg/L for new/professional drivers. (3) Penalties for exceeding limits: €500–€1,000 fine, 3–6 month license suspension (first offense). (4) Refusal to take a breathalyzer test: €1,000 fine, 6 month license suspension. (5) Driving under the influence of drugs: Similar penalties to alcohol. (6) Driving with prescribed medications: If medications impair driving (labeled 'No conducir'), you should not drive. If stopped and impaired, you face penalties. The safest approach: Do not drink and drive at all. Spain has zero-tolerance enforcement in many areas, especially on holiday weekends. Taxis and Uber are readily available and affordable on the Costa Blanca; use them rather than risk driving after consuming alcohol.

subsections.heading: Parking Rules
subsections.content: Parking in Spain is regulated: (1) No-parking zones (línea amarilla, yellow line on the curb): Indicate no parking at any time. (2) Limited parking zones (línea blanca, white line): Indicate restricted parking times (usually 8 a.m.–8 p.m.). (3) Permitted parking zones (blue zones in many towns): Require payment. Parking meters or permit systems apply; cost is typically €1–€2/hour. (4) Resident parking zones (green zones): Limited to residents with resident permits; visitors are allowed for 30 minutes. (5) Underground and multi-story car parks: Available in most towns; cost €1–€2/hour or €8–€15/day. Parking without payment in restricted zones results in fines (€30–€300) and possible vehicle immobilization (grúa). If your car is towed, you must pay a retrieval fee (€150–€300) plus parking fines to recover it. On the Costa Blanca, major town centers (Torrevieja, Benidorm, Alicante) have extensive parking management; read signs carefully to avoid violations.

subsections.heading: Motorways and Toll Roads
subsections.content: Spain has numerous toll motorways (autopistas de peaje) requiring payment: (1) How tolls work: At toll booths (casetas de peaje), you pay cash or card based on distance traveled and vehicle type. (2) Cost: Typically €0.05–€0.10 per km; a 50 km journey might cost €3–€5. (3) Payment: Most toll booths accept credit/debit cards and cash. Some motorways use electronic systems (VIA) allowing prepayment or monthly billing. (4) Planning: Use a GPS or online tool (Google Maps indicates toll roads) to plan routes. Avoiding tolls often means using slower regional roads (carreteras nacionales or comarcales), which are free but slower. (5) Important motorways on the Costa Blanca: AP-7 (coastal motorway from Alicante to Valencia, tolled sections), AP-36 (Benidorm to inland), various regional motorways. Failure to pay tolls can result in fines issued by mail months after travel; these are serious and should be paid promptly. If you rent a car or have a rental, clarify toll responsibility with the rental company.

subsections.heading: Traffic Violation Fines (Multas de Tráfico)
subsections.content: Spanish traffic police (Guardias Civiles, Policia Local) issue fines for various violations: (1) No seatbelt: €200 per person. (2) Speeding: €100–€1,000+ depending on extent (see speed limit section). (3) Mobile phone use while driving: €200 fine (hands-free is permitted). (4) Running red light or stop sign: €200. (5) Parking violations (no-parking zone, double-parking): €30–€300 depending on severity. (6) Headlights not on in poor visibility: €200 (headlights required during daytime on certain roads and in all conditions on motorways). (7) Tinted windows (illegal if too dark): €200. (8) Child safety seat violations: €200. (9) Failing to carry mandatory equipment (warning triangles, vests): €200. (10) Driving with expired license: €300–€1,000 fine plus vehicle impoundment possible. (11) Driving without insurance: €300–€600 fine plus vehicle impoundment.

subsections.heading: License Points System (Sistema de Puntos)
subsections.content: Spain operates a driver license points system. All new licenses start with 12 points; violations deduct points. When points reach zero, your license is suspended (perdida de vigencia). Points deductions: (1) Speeding: 1–6 points depending on excess. (2) Drink driving: 4–6 points. (3) Seatbelt violation: 3 points. (4) Red light: 3 points. (5) Mobile phone use: 3 points. If you lose all 12 points, your license is suspended for a minimum of 3 months. You must pass a revalidation course and exam to restore your license. For serious violations (reckless driving, hit-and-run, DUI), points deduction can be more severe. Conversely, if you do not receive any violations within 3 years, you regain 1 point (capped at 12). The points system encourages safe driving; accumulate violations cautiously, or you will lose your license.

subsections.heading: Serious Offenses and License Suspension
subsections.content: Serious violations can result in immediate license suspension: (1) Reckless driving (conducción temeraria): Speeds exceeding 80 km/h over limit; 4–6 month license suspension, €600–€1,000 fine. (2) Driving without a license: 1 month–1 year suspension, €300–€1,000 fine, possible car impoundment. (3) Drunk driving (BAC over 0.6 mg/dL): 3–6 month suspension, €500–€1,000 fine. (4) Hit-and-run: 1–4 year suspension, €600–€3,000 fine, possible jail time. (5) Causing injury while driving: 1–4 year suspension, €600–€6,000 fine, possible jail time. These offenses are not minor; they carry serious consequences. Always drive responsibly and within limits.

sections.title: Practical Tips for Safe Driving on the Costa Blanca

subsections.heading: Road Conditions and Hazards
subsections.content: (1) Summer heat: Extreme heat (35–40°C) can cause tire blowouts and engine overheating. Check tire pressure and coolant regularly. (2) Sun glare: Strong Mediterranean sun creates glare on windscreens; sunshades and polarized sunglasses are helpful. (3) Coastal roads: Winding hillside roads (e.g., around Javea, Calpe) require caution; visibility is limited, and tourist drivers may be unfamiliar with roads. (4) Mountain roads: Hairpin turns and steep gradients demand careful speed and gear management; hold brakes and watch for loose gravel. (5) Night driving: Poor street lighting outside town centers; use full-beam headlights when safe. (6) Rain (November–March): Mediterranean rains are occasional but can be heavy; water on roads creates aquaplaning risk. Reduce speed on wet roads. (7) Wildlife: In rural areas, wild boar and other animals can cross roads, especially at dawn/dusk. Be alert. (8) Tourist drivers: During summer, roads are congested with tourist drivers unfamiliar with Spanish roads; expect slower traffic and be patient.

subsections.heading: Vehicle Maintenance
subsections.content: Maintain your vehicle to avoid breakdowns and safety issues: (1) Regular servicing: Every 15,000 km or annually, whichever comes first. (2) Tire checks: Check pressure monthly and tread depth (minimum 1.6 mm); replace tires when worn. (3) Brakes: Have brake pads and discs inspected annually. (4) Fluids: Check oil, coolant, brake fluid, and power steering fluid monthly. (5) Battery: In summer heat, batteries deteriorate faster; test annually. (6) Air conditioning: Service air conditioning before summer to ensure cooling. (7) Windscreen wipers: Replace seasonally (winter for rainy season). (8) Lights: Check all lights monthly. Spanish garages (talleres) are available in all towns; costs for servicing are reasonable (€150–€300 for basic service). Major dealerships are more expensive but offer warranty on work.

subsections.heading: Navigation and Route Planning
subsections.content: (1) GPS/Sat-nav: Essential for navigating Spanish roads. Use Google Maps, Waze, or Garmin with updated maps. (2) Toll avoidance: Use GPS to identify toll roads and free alternatives. (3) Apps for fines: Use apps (RadarBot, Speedcam Radar) to identify speed cameras and warnings. (4) Fuel planning: Fuel is cheaper at self-service stations; plan refueling to avoid expensive motorway services. Cost is approximately €1.40–€1.60/liter depending on fuel type and station. (5) Breakdown assistance: Join roadside assistance (asisitencia de viaje) through your insurer or independently (RACE, ADA). Costs €50–€150/year and cover vehicle recovery, repairs, and accommodation if stranded. (6) Language: Carry a Spanish-English dictionary or use your phone translator if communicating with police or mechanics.

subsections.heading: Dealing with Fines and Penalties
subsections.content: (1) At-the-spot fines: Police may issue on-the-spot fines (multas in situ). You receive a fine receipt and can pay within 15 days at a traffic office or online (descuentos for early payment, typically 50% off). (2) Mailed fines: Some violations result in fines mailed to your address; deadline to pay is usually 30 days. (3) Payment options: Pay at traffic offices (Tráfico), banks, or online (www.dgt.es for online payment). (4) Appeals: If you believe a fine is unjust, you can appeal within 30 days; appeals must be submitted in Spanish, often requiring a lawyer. (5) Non-payment: Failing to pay fines can result in license suspension, vehicle impoundment, or legal proceedings. It is advisable to pay fines promptly. (6) Foreigner identification: If fined and you do not have a Spanish NIE, provide your passport and foreign address; authorities will pursue collection through your home country's authorities (especially EU countries with reciprocal agreements).

content.conclusion:
Driving on the Costa Blanca offers freedom and flexibility to explore the region's beautiful coastal towns, inland villages, and Mediterranean landscapes. However, driving safely and legally requires understanding Spanish traffic rules, insurance requirements, and licensing regulations. Whether you are exchanging your foreign license for a Spanish one, purchasing a car, or navigating the roads daily, this guide provides essential information to help you drive confidently and responsibly. Key takeaways: (1) Your foreign license is valid in Spain (2 years for EU, 6 months for non-EU), but consider exchanging it for a Spanish license for convenience. (2) Buying a car in Spain is accessible and affordable; budget €4,000–€20,000 for a reliable used or new vehicle. (3) Mandatory insurance (terceros minimum, todo riesgo recommended) costs €600–€3,000/year. (4) Spanish traffic rules are strict; obey speed limits, wear seatbelts, do not drink and drive, and respect parking regulations. (5) The ITV is mandatory every 2 years for cars over 4 years old; budget €60–€120. (6) Fines for violations range from €100 to €1,000+ depending on severity; the points system can lead to license suspension. Drive responsibly, respect local rules, and enjoy the freedom and adventure that comes with ownership and driving on the beautiful Costa Blanca.
